current.title: English Teacher
current.description: Teach literary analysis and writing through close reading, supportive, discussion-centered classrooms, and an emphasis on authentic student voice. Led a collaborative redesign of the 9th grade English curriculum. Developed elective courses drawing on my graduate work in Russian and world literature. Currently leading the school's adaptation to Artificial Intelligence. Beyond the classroom, serve as advisor, coach, and dorm parent, and founded an outdoor leadership program.

courses.name: Fundamentals in Literature and Composition
courses.description: A skills-based course redesigned collaboratively with the 9th grade English team. The curriculum centers on competency development in close reading, writing in many forms, metacognition and character growth, grounded in place-based learning that uses Washington, DC as a living text.
courses.previewContext: Sample assignments, student work, and course artifacts.

courses.name: Chekhov
courses.description: A single-author course tracing Chekhov's development from early work to the extraordinary pieces of his final years. His short stories and plays become a lens for exploring realist aesthetics, while his humble, humanist worldview offers a model for living.
courses.previewContext: Sample assignments, student work, and course artifacts.

courses.name: Gothic Literature Across Two Centuries
courses.description: Gothic literature reinterpreted across cultures and centuries. Each society's use of gothic tropes reveals what it finds unspeakably terrifying, making the genre a window into collective fears—from Victorian anxieties to contemporary Latin American gothic.
courses.previewContext: Sample assignments, student work, and course artifacts.

courses.name: Middle Eastern Voices
courses.description: Contemporary literature from across the Middle East, chosen to complicate and contest stereotypical understandings of the region. The emphasis on diversity of perspective, genre, and content teaches broader lessons about humility and curiosity when encountering unfamiliar cultures.
courses.previewContext: Sample assignments, student work, and course artifacts.

courses.name: Russian Short Fiction
courses.description: The Russian short story tradition from Pushkin through contemporary writers, organized around major literary movements. The course culminates in a creative writing project where students write their own story in the style of an author of their choice.

leadership.title: AI Task Force Lead
leadership.description: Lead Episcopal's adaptation to the rise of Artificial Intelligence. Facilitate faculty workshops on AI integration, developing training resources and implementation frameworks. Shape institutional policy emphasizing ethical, honorable and effective integration of AI in collaboration with the Leadership Team.
